May be an image of text that says 'what we see refusing to open crying physical behaviors TOOTH BRUSHING STRUGGLES "I'm tired" a new experience "I'm overwhelmed" the.dentistmom a change in routine over stimulation fear of the unknown loss of control COMMUNICATION what we don't see'.

node.text:
✨LIKE & SHARE WITH A FRIEND. 💬: When did you start toothbrushing? How long did it take for your little one to adapt?

We started brushing Olivia’s teeth around 8 mos. It took Olivia almost a full YEAR to develop a comfortable relationship with toothbrushing. It was not an easy journey for us — even as dentists.

____________

Let’s try to understand WHY your child may struggle with toothbrushing.

🦷 The face is a personal area, and it can be overwhelming for many kids to have another individual in their mouth. Toothbrushing introduces new physical textures (bristles of the brush, texture of the paste), new flavors, and many other new sensations.

🦷 Toothbrushing is a task that is completed at the end of the day. At this time, your child is at their crankiest. They’re tired, they’ve had a whole day of power struggles (being told “no” & being given instruction). Like adults after a long day, they may just not “feel like” brushing.

🦷 On top of all of that, toothbrushing is a NEW task, and most children need time to adapt to build confidence when adapting to anything new & exploring the unknown.

If your little one is crying when you first start brushing,
This is 100% normal.
Crying is a form of communication.

If you feel discouraged by the toothbrushing struggles,
Try to understand from your child’s point of view why an everyday task can actually be more complex.

If you feel like giving up,
I understand it’s hard - I see you.
I encourage you to keep trying.

Even if it’s just a few seconds of brushing a day, the more that brushing is normalized as “routine” - the quicker your little one will learn. Avoidance will only increase their sensory aversion to the experience.

It is important to give our children space and allow them to hold boundaries. And it’s equally important to help them navigate through a challenging task — one that they may not enjoy, but is important for their overall health.

Whatever emotion your child experiences during toothbrushing,
Acknowledge their feelings. Talk them through “WHY” it’s important.
Accept that it’s hard for them. Guide them.

And remember,
You are not alone in the struggles.

❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by dr. helen mo on August 10, 2021 tagging @she_mums_n_draws. May be an image of text.

node.text:
LIKE & DROP A ❤️ if you can relate. 💬: what’s the biggest adaptation you’ve made as a parent?

💌: artwork by @she_mums_n_draws

____________________

When Olivia was a baby,
she followed the “textbook.”

She slept in generous 6-8 hour stretches with minimal “training”. We would place her in the crib, do a quick “I love you,” and she would drift off peacefully as we enjoyed the rest of our night uninterrupted.

Now in her toddler years,
Olivia is the opposite.

EVERY night (at the minimum),
we have a multi step bedtime routine,
we struggle, we cuddle,
we tuck her in, do our kisses,
we stay with her until she falls asleep.

Then there’s a short pause, before I end up back on the floor next to her crib. We have our rare nights when Olivia sleeps independently — but often, she needs more.

It’s not ever how I imagined I would *parent*.
My mom guilt hits hard every time I’m asked — “Is Olivia sleeping through the night?” Then followed by the unending questions — “Have you tried…? Why don’t you…?”

The answer is: Yes, we have.
We’ve tried it all.
 
Instead, I’ve learned to parent not just any child, but Olivia — MY daughter.

OUR experience.
OUR journey.

One that doesn’t involve a textbook,
But constant adaptation to each other.

So, I’m “training” myself to take a step back,
🤍 to accept Olivia for the beautiful person she is
🤍 to embrace the chaos & the imperfection of parenthood
🤍 to treasure this phase where she needs me more than ever

Because I know it’ll be only too soon when I’ll miss these moments.

The gentle rhythm of her breathing,
Her love-filled eyes when she wakes up to my face,
And her tiny hands reaching out for mine.

Because these moments always pass,
more quickly than my heart can fathom.
…too quickly.

🤍🤍🤍

node.text:
❤️: LIKE & SAVE FOR LATER.
💬: How did your little ones teeth come in? What age were they?

**REPOSTING for all my new followers!**

Welcome to @the.dentistmom.

I’m Helen Mo, a pediatric dentist in the Bay Area — here to share my motherhood with my 2 year old Olivia & some healthy teeth tips on the side.

This is my personal page and not for profit. I don’t get through every DM or comment, but I try my best to create content based on the FAQs.

Mostly, this page is a community where we can all come together — in a non judgmental way — and support one another.

Thanks for being here!

_______________________

REMEMBER:

🤍 Every child develops at their own pace.

🤍 There is a wide range of variability when the first tooth may appear (some even have them when they’re born!) so don’t worry if your child doesn’t follow the norm!

🤍 Every child is different, and your child's teeth also come in all shapes & sizes.

Your child may not follow the textbook examples,
And that’s ok.

_______________________

WHAT YOU COULD SEE:

⭐️ SPACED OUT TEETH: gaps between the teeth are a good thing! We need those spaces for the larger permanent teeth that replace them in the future. Plus, the gaps allow the saliva to naturally clean the teeth.

⭐️ CROWDED TEETH: this may mean your child doesn't have enough jaw space for the permanent teeth. It also means that you need to be extra diligent about cleaning & flossing! Crowding makes it easier for cavities to develop.

⭐️ DISCOLORED TEETH: if your baby's tooth doesn't look white & shiny, you may want to consult a dentist. It could be a number of things: cavities, an injury or infection, staining from iron supplements, certain medications taken during tooth formation in utero, or genetic. The teeth could also be completely healthy, without anything wrong at all.

⭐️ MISSING TEETH: your dentist will determine if a radiograph may be needed to assess for missing teeth.

⭐️ TOO MANY TEETH: sometimes your child may have an extra tooth

Any other anomalies to baby teeth are similar to having a birthmark. They make your child special!

A dentist can help you monitor them.

node.text:
SWIPE & drop a ❤️ if you can relate. By: @cryitoutmom & @sketchmomlife

This week Olivia’s daycare is off, and I’m feeling the push & pull of motherhood extra strongly.

So complex,
Yet so simple.

Wanting it to pass faster,
Yet wanting everything to slow down.

node.text:
LIKE & SAVE for later. 💬: What’s your child’s favorite toothbrush? Share some ideas for other parents below!

🦷: Check out my amazon shop (link in bio) for more product recs.

Hi 👋🏼 I’m Helen Mo, a pediatric dentist and mom to 2 year old Olivia — shown in this video.

Olivia hated brushing when she got her first teeth at 8 mos, and it honestly became one of our most dreaded routines. But I share our journey to let parents know that even a dentist struggles with teethbrushing.

You are not alone 🤍

______________

FAQS:

⭐️ When can I start brushing?
Once the teeth are in, use a soft bristle toothbrush to adequately remove the plaque and keep the gums healthy. Starting early helps prevent cavities too!

⭐️ What can I do before teeth are in?
It’s never too early to introduce oral desensitization to prepare your baby for the sensation of brushing before your little one even gets teeth. You can use a silicone brush, a finger brush, or even a clean washcloth.

⭐️ Should I brush for my baby & toddler?
Yes! You can give your little one some independence by letting them explore, but always pair it with a good brushing by an adult.

______________

✔️ sharing to IG stories is highly encouraged & I’m so grateful for all those who do!

💌 DM me for permission prior to re-posting videos of my daughter on your own page

❌ please do not take videos of my daughter for your own resale & self promotion

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by dr. helen mo in Children’s Fairyland with @common_wild. May be an image of text that says 'THE NIGHTS MIGHT FEEL LONELY BUT YOU ARE NOT ALONE *Paula.Kuka'.

node.text:
Here’s a beautiful reminder from @common_wild — some of those nights feel so lonely, but…

You are not alone 🤍

💬: how was your night?

We’ve been having some rough ones this week with Olivia being sick. 😵‍💫😴

But I’m trying my best —
To embrace the snuggles,
To treasure these moments that I know I’ll eventually miss,
And to just take it a day at a time.

💌: tag a parent & share the love

node.text:
LIKE & DROP a ❤️ if your little one is currently teething!

💬: What teething solutions worked for your little one? Share some ideas below for other parents! 
When it comes to teething, every child responds differently. It may take some time to find the teething relief option that works best for your child.

Don't forget to also be gentle on yourself. Teething is a difficult process for a parent, so embrace the baby snuggles, and remember it is not forever. Give yourself some love, too.

Try something that suits your child’s developmental stage.

❓Are they unable to chew on a teether? 

❓Are they able to hold objects with a palmar grasp?

❓Can they eat solids? 

________________________________

TEETHING SAFETY TIPS:

⭐️ NOT EVERYTHING MARKETED FOR TEETHING BELONGS IN YOUR CHILD’S MOUTH!

Do your homework, and make sure anything you're introducing to your little one is safe. If you’re ever in doubt, consult your pediatrician or dentist.

⭐️ Supervise your baby when there’s any teething object in the mouth.

⭐️ Look for soft chewing toys that won’t damage the gums or teeth.

⭐️ Check that frozen objects are not too cold. Thaw as needed or refrigerate instead.

⭐️ CHECK INGREDIENTS if using any homeopathic remedies or oral gels. Avoid words like “benzocaine” “alcohol” or “belladonna.” When in doubt, please have your pediatrician or pediatric dentist take a look prior to introducing to your child.

⭐️ If using any OTC analgesics (such as Tylenol or Motrin), please dose medicine by your baby’s WEIGHT. If unsure of the dosing, consult your pediatric advice line or a pharmacist.

SWIPE & LIKE if you can relate. Follow @marycatherinestarr for more!

Lately, there’s rarely a second Olivia leaves my side.

It’s sweet,
And nothing makes my mama heart happier than when she says “cuddles please.”

But the other part of me desperately craves just a few moments to myself.

💬: what’s your favorite activity if you (ever) get “alone time”?

node.text:
LIKE & 💌 TAG a friend who has a little one! Follow @the.dentistmom for more oral health tips.

💬: Drop a ❤️ if your little one is teething. What are some of your top teething tips for other parents? 
I’ve summarized some of the most frequent FAQ’s into this visual: 1: how to care for the teeth through the teething discomfort
2: how to cleanse sensitive teething areas 3: how to care for the teeth once they come in

Big shoutout to my daughter Olivia for letting me capture such great pictures of her first little teeth.

🤍

READ BELOW FOR MORE!  ________________________________

⭐️ What should I do before teeth come in? You can massage the teething areas with a finger brush or even a clean finger to alleviate symptoms of discomfort. As a bonus, it can prepare your baby for the sensation of brushing in the future!

⭐️ HELP! How do I clean the teething areas when the teeth are trying to break through?
If your child is sensitive in the teething areas, try using a warm damp washcloth to cleanse the area as needed. You can still brush the remaining non-teething areas as usual.

⭐️ What should I do once teeth come in?
Once the teeth are in, use a soft bristle toothbrush with a small smear or rice size of fluoride toothpaste (as per the AAPD and AAP recommendations).

Start by brushing a 3-5 seconds a tooth, and slowly building your child’s brushing tolerance — even if it’s only seconds over the course of weeks!

⭐️ What if I see bleeding when brushing? Minimal bleeding may be present when brushing before the teeth are fully erupted — (similar to the bleeding you see if you floss after not flossing for a while!). However, if you see persistent or uncontrollable bleeding, this may not be normal. Consult your dentist.

⭐️ When should my baby’s first dental visit be? See a dentist by age 1 or 6 mos after the first tooth erupts, or if no teeth by 18 mos.

🤍🤍🤍

Remember, just like any routine, brushing may take time to build, so have patience as your little one slowly adapts to having their new teeth brushed.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by dr. helen mo in San Francisco Bay Area. May be an image of text that says 'I know it's hard. I know it can be hard to wake up every day and have these little people rely on you. I know sometimes it's hard to feel like your world is so small. I want to remind you, you are the world. You are the world that your little ones revolve around. You are their nurture, their home, and their comfort. You are to them, and I hope even on your days you know how special you are, especially to these little people. anonymous the.dentistmom'.

node.text:
A little mid week motivation
— because parenting is hard.

How are you feeling this week?
👍🏼 or 👎🏼?

💌: share with a friend who could use some extra love today!

node.text:
LIKE & SAVE FOR LATER ❤️ Let’s talk soft bristle toothbrushes & how to introduce them.

💬: How many teeth does your little one have? What’s your biggest brushing struggle?

⭐️ Read below for my tips!

If your child struggles with brushing, remember that the face is such a personal area and they may need time to find oral healthcare normal. But the more frequent the exposure, the more routine toothbrushing will become.

All children benefit from consistent, and daily exposure when learning new routines.

🦷 BROWSE my Amazon Shop (link in bio) for fun toothbrush options.

______________

⭐️ TEETH ARE IN?
Use a soft bristle toothbrush to adequately remove the plaque and keep the gums healthy.
▫️Pick a toothbrush that makes brushing fun - it could be a favorite character, one that lights up, or one that plays music.
▫️Angle the toothbrush 45 degrees towards the gum, and brush in gentle circles.
▫️Don’t forget to brush all around, including the insides and the tops of the chewing surfaces.

______________

⭐️ INTRODUCING THE TOOTHBRUSH:
STEP-BY-STEP.

1️⃣ EXPLORE & PLAY.
Under supervision, encourage your child’s interest by allowing them to hold the toothbrush & examine at their own pace.

2️⃣ TOUCH & FEEL.
First, don't even brush the teeth. Aim to have your child adapt to the feeling of the spinning.

Start on other body parts, then slowly move up to the area of the face. Start at the outside of the cheek/lips, then the inside of the mouth, and finally rest on top of the teeth or on the gums.

3️⃣ FREQUENT EXPOSURE & DESENSITIZATION.
Every time you brush, set a goal. For example, start with a goal of 1 tooth per brushing, then once that is mastered, increase the goal to 2 teeth, etc. Brush less teeth at a time, but more frequently throughout the day.

Even building your child’s tolerance by a few seconds over the course of weeks is a huge win!

4️⃣ POSITIVE REINFORCEMENT.
Every time you make an improvement, no matter how small, CHEER & make it exciting.
